title: 7-Year-Old Female with Unexplained Screening Failures
chief_complaint: I hear fine, but I failed the hearing test at school twice.

problem_summary.onset: Identified during recent public school hearing screenings.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: None reported; child denies hearing difficulty.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Parents are seeking an explanation for the apparent high-frequency hearing loss after an otologist found no physical abnormalities.

history.present_illness: The patient failed public school hearing screenings twice. Parents consulted an otologist who found no explanation for the apparent high-frequency loss and referred the child for further study.
history.otologic_history: Otologic exam by previous physician was unremarkable.
history.patient_goals: Determine if hearing loss is real and identify the cause.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral high-frequency air-conduction hearing loss appearing at 2000 Hz and sloping to moderate severity at 4000-8000 Hz. Bone conduction thresholds are normal (0 dB HL) across all tested frequencies, indicating a significant air-bone gap in the high frequencies.

numeric_results.Bone_Conduction: 0 dB HL at 500, 1000, 2000, and 4000 Hz bilaterally

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Recognition Thresholds (SRT) are in good agreement with low-frequency pure tone averages. Word recognition scores (SRS) are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Acoustic reflexes are present at normal levels.

tests.name: ABR
tests.key_findings: All waves normal; interpeak latencies normal; latency-intensity function normal.

tests.name: TEOAE
tests.key_findings: Transient Evoked Otoacoustic Emissions are present bilaterally.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with an apparent bilateral high-frequency conductive hearing loss when tested with standard headphones, characterized by significant air-bone gaps at 4000 Hz despite normal bone conduction. However, all objective measures—including tympanometry, acoustic reflexes, ABR, and TEOAEs—are completely normal. The discrepancy between the air-conduction thresholds and the normal physiological measures (especially OAEs and reflexes) suggests the hearing loss is artifactual, likely caused by collapsing ear canals under the pressure of supra-aural headphones.
counseling_points: Your daughter has normal hearing in both ears.
The 'hearing loss' seen on the school screenings and the initial graph was caused by the headphones pushing her soft ear canals closed (collapsing canals), blocking the sound.
We confirmed her hearing is normal using tests that don't put pressure on the ear (like the echo test/OAEs) and by looking at her bone conduction responses.
She does not need medical treatment or hearing aids. We will provide a letter for her school and doctor explaining these findings.
notes_for_actor: Portray a healthy 7-year-old who is unconcerned and insists she hears fine.
If playing the parent, express confusion about why the school keeps failing her and why the previous doctor couldn't find anything wrong.
The key to this case is the physical property of the ear cartilage; the 'hearing loss' is created by the equipment itself.
